comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Despite the title, this is not a canal lock, it's the lock at the weir on the Shannon at Athlone. You can see the very same foreground stonework, water level (in that notch) and metal lock-gate-opening gizmo in my (relatively) recent photo, here:

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks for saving our (my!) blushes there. Have changed description, and in return, can tell you that the gizmo is officially a gate winch...

So is that the canal at all?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: No, it's just that lock you can see in the photo above, there's no canal at all. See an aerial view from Google maps linked below, the lock is to the left of the weir: maps.google.ie/maps?hl=en&ll=53.422947,-7.939392&...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks! Obliterated all mention of canal from tags...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
Here's one of the gate winches without it's coverings and a close up of a plate inscription from another. You can see the winch could have been operated by one or two people and it originally used chains.

Thomas Rhodes was Chief Engineer on the harbour project, the technical guy in charge.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03/4853081700/in/set-72157617205370073/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03/3607492455/in/set-72157617205370073]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I was in town yesterday, and took this shot for comparison:

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I didn't recognise the church steeple at the extreme right of shot, and it's because the Methodist church on Northgate street has lost its steeple! In Streetview today. In your nli archive The Archive shot says it was a Presbyterian church at the time, but I think it is wrong. The osi historic map says Methodist, and the Presbyterian church was across the river, converted to be a Restaurant some years ago.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Any idea what happened - how/why/when it lost its steeple??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I bet you'll try to find out!  ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: These are really charming old pictures and i really enjoy seeing them, thank you for sharing.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From archiseek: A tall spire-like lantern was originally placed over the west end, but that became unsafe and was removed in the 1950s.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In a strange coincidence, the Presbyterian church on the left of shot also lost it's spire in the 1950s! From the Locke Restaurant website: In the 1950s the tall spire of the Presbyterian Church was bought by Fr McGivney and re-erected on the Catholic church at Curry on the approach to Longford town where it was blessed by the Bishop of Ardagh and Clonmacnoise, Dr McNamee in June 1957. Which means this is it, here, in streetview.
